page.title: 15DIGSWELL VIADUCT
page.content: Near our school is a big railway viaduct.It was built in 1850 so that trains could cross the valley of the river Mimram on their way north from London.It was made of bricks made from local red clay but later it was encased in dark bricks which we see now.You can see some of the old bricks on the river bed. People said the viaduct could not be built because the ground was too soggy and unfirm but the contractor, Thomas Brassey, used lots of navvies called the'Tray Bong Boys' to dig deep foundations by hand.They camped in shacks on meadows where horses are now kept.The viaduct has forty arches and the design was copied from a Roman aquaduct.Intercity trains can still go over the viaduct at full speed so it must have been well built. {JEANETTE SUGG(11)
